Title: The Upcycled Clinic: A Global Ethnography of Material Creativity in Contemporary Medicine

This ethnographic project aims to investigate the phenomenon of material creativity in clinics, focusing on the ways healthcare professionals and support staff repurpose and reuse materials to address resource shortages and wastefulness. Through a globally oriented study, we will explore the conditions that enable creative material engagement in clinics, shedding light on the improvisational practices that often go unnoticed in medical settings.

Our five-subproject design will take place in Antarctica, Ghana, the Netherlands, the U.S., and the U.K., involving ethnographers, cleaners, and laundry staff as participants. We will employ fieldwork, interviews, and analysis of open datasets to gather data. The proposed study will advance theories of materiality, addressing questions of resilience and innovation in the workplace. Our practical outcomes will articulate the conditions necessary for healthcare creativity and local solutions to wastefulness and shortage. Title: The Upcycled Clinic: A Global Ethnography of Material Creativity in Contemporary Medicine

The Upcycled Clinic is a pioneering ethnographic project that tackles the pressing issue of wastefulness in medicine by exploring the creative ways healthcare professionals repurpose materials in clinical settings. Through a globally oriented study, we will investigate the conditions that foster innovative material engagements in five clinics located in Antarctica, Ghana, the Netherlands, the U.S., and the U.K. Our research team, comprising ethnographers, cleaners, and laundry staff, will employ a mixed-methods approach, combining fieldwork, interviews, and analysis of open datasets to uncover the improvisational strategies employed by healthcare workers to overcome resource shortages and minimize waste.

This project marks a significant departure from traditional hospital ethnographies, which have focused primarily on patient encounters. By shifting the lens to the material practices of healthcare workers, we will develop new insights into the ways in which creativity and resourcefulness are mobilized to address everyday challenges in the clinic. The study's contributions will be threefold: advancing theories of materiality, addressing questions of resilience and innovation in the workplace, and developing novel methods for reusing and sharing research materials. Ultimately, our research aims to articulate the conditions necessary for healthcare creativity and identify local solutions to wastefulness and shortage, informing strategies for more sustainable and effective healthcare systems worldwide.
